May 25, 1922
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
Your letter of May 15 enclosing the bill for
stenographic services in connection with the history
of yellow fever was received and the check has gone
forward from the Comptroller's office.

We are sorry that you are having trouble with
your hip. If the long walks to the Library of Congress
have anything to do with your difficulty, Mr Rose thinks
you should make use of a taxicab.

It has occurred to us that it might be more con-
venient for you to have a small advance on account of
expenses for this work. We are accordingly asking the
Comptroller's office to send you a check for $100 for
this purpose. When that has been used, if you will
send a statement of the expenditures you will be reimbursed
for them. In this way you can always have funds on hand
Doctor Henry R Carter
May 25, 1922
2.
which can be used for incidental expenses connected
with this work.

I hope that the Hopkins Hospital treated you
well and that you are already feeling fit again.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, Florence M. Read Doctor Henry R Carter
2121 California Street, N.W.
Washington, D.C.
